title: Schedule
text:
Date
Time
Topic




Thurs., Sept. 8
9:00 - 9:30 am
Intro to animal movement ecology and behavioral state estimation



9:30 - 10:15 am
Exploratory data analysis



10:15 - 10:30 am
Coffee break



10:30 - 11:00 am
Lecture on state-space models (SSMs)



11:00 am - 12:00 pm
Analyze tracks w/ SSMs via foieGras



12:00 - 1:30 pm
Lunch



1:30 - 2:00 pm
Lecture on hidden Markov models (HMMs)



2:00 - 3:00 pm
Analyze tracks w/ HMMs via momentuHMM



3:00 - 3:15 pm
Coffee break



3:15 - 3:45 pm
Lecture on non-parametric Bayesian segmentation and clustering models



3:45 - 4:45 pm
Analyze tracks w/ segment- and observation-level models via bayesmove



4:45 - 5:00 pm
Recap and guidelines for method selection







Fri., Sept. 9
9:00 - 9:30 am
Intro to animal spatial ecology and space-use metrics



9:30 - 10:00 am
Estimate space-use by minimum convex polygon (MCP) via amt



10:00 - 10:15 am
Coffee break



10:15 - 10:45 am
Lecture on kernel density estimation (KDE)



10:45 am - 12:00 pm
Estimate space-use by KDE via amt



12:00 - 1:30 pm
Lunch



1:30 - 2:00 pm
Lecture on autocorrelated KDE (AKDE)



2:00 - 3:00 pm
Estimate space-use by AKDE via ctmm



3:00 - 3:15 pm
Coffee break



3:15 - 3:45 pm
Lecture on dynamic Brownian bridge movement model (dBBMM)



3:45 - 4:45 pm
Estimate space-use by dBBMM via move



4:45 - 5:00 pm
Recap and guidelines for method selection

title: Resources related to covered topics
text:
One section on published papers (or pre-prints) that present these different methods for animal movement analyses (i.e., further readings)
Another section on online resources for using each of the different R packages presented (i.e., package websites, vignettes)
Any other relevant miscellaneous resources

title: Space-use and behavioral state estimation from animal telemetry data
text:
Additionally, a set of guidelines will be presented as to how practitioners should decide which method is best for their project and data needs. The focus of this workshop will be on satellite telemetry data (i.e., GPS, Argos, light-level geolocation) for aquatic species using the R programming language, but is applicable to terrestrial species and some instances of acoustic telemetry.
This workshop assumes that participants have an intermediate knowledge of the R programming language and are generally familiar with animal telemetry data.

title: How to prepare for this workshop
text: Provide explicit instructions that attendees should attempt to install all software at least 2 days before the workshop. That way I can help if they run into issues and can’t install or run some of the necessary R packages.

title: Troubleshooting computer problems
text: Point attendees towards relevant websites, primarily related to issues w/ compiler errors or TMB install.
